item.title: [Lyon, France] Outdoors in Lyon: Parks and a Roman Theater
item.description:
Roman Theater, Lyon, France

Lyon has numerous parks and open spaces where you can enjoy the outdoors. Besides ourÂ walks through various neighborhoods for “mural-spotting” and the visits toÂ the Parc de la TÃªte dâ€™Or and the riverside promenade, we strolled throughÂ other smaller parks and visited the lovely Roman Theater in the city.

If you enjoy the outdoors, here are some places that you could add to your itinerary in Lyon, formerlyÂ known as Lugdunum, an important Roman city in Gaul.

 

Croix-Rousse Neighborhood: Jardin des Chartreux and Parc Gros Caillou

Head to the unique Croix-Rousse neighborhood, known as the home of the silk weaversÂ or canuts. Walk up the slopes of the hill and reflect onÂ the historyÂ of the district.

The Jardin des Chartreux is a green space on the steep slopes of the Croix-Rousse hill. Spend some timeÂ in this garden with picturesque views of the Fourvi_Ã¨_re hill and the basilica. Gaze at the river SaÃ´ne meandering its way through Lyon.

And then, if the climb uphill was exhausting, enter one of the cafes or restaurants on the plateau of Croix-Rousse. Situated atop the hill, this area has a vibrant feel and unique charm. Take a break at the small Parc Gros Caillou, watch the kids playing in the park, enjoy a chat with a friend or loved one, and admire the panoramic vista from this location.

Junior’s spirits were high at both the parks and we loved ambling through the Croix-Rousse district.

Exploring the Croix-Rousse district. Lyon, France

Parc Gros Caillou atop the Croix-Rousse hill. Lyon, France

View of FourviÃ¨re from Jardin des Chartreux. Lyon, France

 

 

Ferry Ride and Confluence Park

Hop on to a ferry to be transported to another world. Look out for the “Confluence” ferry atÂ the Hotel de Ville-St. Paul boarding point and enjoy the ride along theÂ SaÃ´ne. The boatÂ passes Pont Bonaparte and other landmarks before reaching the confluence of the RhÃ´ne andÂ SaÃ´ne. Suddenly, the scene undergoes a dramatic change.

A new district with a striking architecture appears ahead. Here isÂ the brand new Confluence district, a neighborhood that has been dramatically transformed. New trendy housing projects and a grand commercial complex have replaced the prisons and warehouses that dominated the area sometime ago. Hop off the ferry and explore the Confluence district.

Stroll through the area for a curtain-raiser toÂ the novelÂ architecture ofÂ the residential buildings. A well-designed park had Junior in a joyous mood, while we looked around at the colorful edifices.

If you are keen on some indoor time, head into the mall and shop, eat, or watch a movie.

The Confluence Ferry. Lyon, France

 

Eye-catching. The Confluence District, Lyon, France

A Park in the Confluence neighborhood. Lyon, France

 

Roman Theater (by funicular) and Fourvi_Ã¨_re

Retrace Lyon’s history by visiting the Roman Theater near the Fourvi_Ã¨_re hill. Take the funicular from Vieux Lyon to Saint Just-Minimes and walk to the site of an ancient Roman Theater.

TheÂ construction of this Roman theater dates back to 15 BC. The well-maintained complex, one of the oldest in France, has three main structures – a theater, an odeum, and a temple. Explore the grounds at a leisurely pace, take the opportunity to test the incredible acoustics, and, if time permits, visit the museum nearby to delve into the historical aspects.

We had a good time exploring the theater and Junior jumped on the chance to climb more steps. However, we gave the museum a miss.

 

Revisiting History at the Roman Theater. Lyon, France

Revisiting History at the Roman Theater. Lyon, France

 

From the Roman theater, walk to the summit of the Fourvi_Ã¨_re hill toÂ visitÂ the Notre Dame de Fourvi_Ã¨_re basilica, an imposing structure that looks over Lyon and is visibleÂ from many parts of the city. The Virgin Mary saved the residents of Lyon fromÂ devastating epidemics of plague and cholera. For many years now, candles are lit and the F_Ãª_te des Lumi_Ã¨_res is celebrated to thank Mary for her protection.

From the Fourvi_Ã¨_re hill, one can board a funicular that descends the hill and halts at Vieux Lyon.

Keeping watch. Notre Dame de FourviÃ¨re, Lyon, France

Basilica of Notre Dame de FourviÃ¨re, Lyon, France

Hop on! Funicular, Lyon, France

 

Other Sights:

Other outdoor attractions and sights include the beautiful Bartholdi fountain in the Place des Terreaux at the base of the Croix-Rousse hill. For another dash of history, you can view the Amphith_Ã©Ã¢_tre des Trois Gaules from outside (access inside the premises is not allowed).

item.title: [Lyon, France] Outdoors in Lyon: The Riverside and a Huge Park
item.description:
Riverside Promenade. River RhÃ´ne, Lyon, France

Our itinerary in Lyon included a great deal of time outdoors and we madeÂ the most of the splendid weather and bright sunshine.

The sprawling Parc de la TÃªte d’OrÂ andÂ the pretty riverside promenade were some of our favorite outdoor spaces in Lyon.

 

Riverside Promenade, Lyon:

The rivers RhÃ´ne and SaÃ´ne wind their way through the gastronomic capital of France. Along the eastern bank of the RhÃ´ne, a long promenade offers visitors and locals a great place to enjoy the outdoors.

We began our stroll near Pont Lafayette, one of the numerousÂ bridges that span the river RhÃ´ne.Â Everyone wasÂ outdoors to enjoy the brilliant sunshine. Some folks walked, some cycled, and others snoozed in the shade. We passed families enjoying a picnic and young parents pushing strollers. Many swans preferred toÂ baskÂ in the sun rather than to cool off in the water.Â We made pit stops at theÂ kids’ play areas where Junior had a gala time.

SeveralÂ boats have been converted into restaurants and barsÂ along the river. They seem to beÂ perfect for a break after a long day.

Our walk along the promenade ended nearÂ Pont Winston Churchill (near the Parc de la TÃªte d’Or). It had been a perfect end to a beautifulÂ day.

Bridge across the River RhÃ´ne. Lyon, France

Riverside Promenade. River RhÃ´ne, Lyon, France

Riverside Promenade. River RhÃ´ne, Lyon, France

 

Parc de la TÃªte d’Or, Lyon:

This huge park, approximately 105 hectares in size, is a vast green spaceÂ in Lyon. We visited the Parc de la TÃªte d’Or several times during our week-long stay in the city. And each time, we discovered a new aspect.

The Lake:

We spent an evening by the lakeside, watching the geese, and Junior made persistent attemptsÂ to converse with them :). The lush grass on the bank was the perfect seat at the end of a long day exploringÂ the city.

Honk, honk!!! The Lake at Parc de la TÃªte d’Or, Lyon, France

The Zoo:

On a sunny morning, we visited the small zoo in the park. The African plain with giraffes and zebras was picturesque,Â andÂ the sight of flamingos wasÂ aÂ treat to the eyes. The crocodiles lazed around while the primates were very active. Needless to say, Junior was excited, and we had a very good time, as well.

Say “AAAA”. The Zoo at Parc de la TÃªte d’Or, Lyon, France

The TouristÂ Train (Le LÃ©zard du Parc):

A little train, Le LÃ©zard du Parc, takes visitors on a tour of the park, and of course, we could not resist the ride. We hopped on to the train near the main entrance, and enjoyed the 20-minute tour with a commentary about the various sections of the park. It was a convenient way to get an introductory tour of the place and, of course, to keep the kids (who were out in large numbers) entertained :).

For more information (time, tariff, etc.) about the train, please visit http://www.loisirs-parcdelatetedor.com/activites-et-loisirs/le-lezard-du-parc

Exploring the parkÂ on FourÂ Wheels and Two Feet:

We explored the park on footÂ and by the _Balad’Or,Â _a 4-wheeled cycle.

Seated comfortablyÂ in theÂ _Balad’Or,_Â we wandered alongÂ the beautiful paths in this vast green lung. Junior was excited to ride in the front seat. I was happy to let B focus on the pedaling effort, while I admiredÂ the surroundings :). Later, we followedÂ variousÂ paths on foot and set off to discover hidden corners.

You can lose yourself inÂ the vast variety of trees, the rose garden, the botanical garden, the orangery, and as a bonus,Â you can spot farm animals!

On one of the many routes, we found ourselves at the Mahatma Gandhi Island (Ile Mahatma Gandhi), an island of tranquility.Â What a pleasant surprise!
